```
prob : sequence, optional
```

to

```
prob : sequence, optional

```

issue.title: ENH: Faster inverse-Wishart sampling

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A new feature or improvement

issue.body: ### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. Currently inverse-Wishart sampling ([here](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/d7f12d38b171f3a6ae841937bb6c2444a1e04b8d/scipy/stats/_multivariate.py#L2957-L3004)) Cholesky decomposes the scale matrix to invert it, then Cholesky decomposes its inverse, samples a Cholesky factor from the Wishart distribution, then inverts it to form an inverse-Wishart matrix. Algorithm 5 in https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15884v1 generates a Cholesky factor of an inverse-Wishart matrix directly. Table 1 shows that for the $\Psi$ parameterization used in `invwishart`, this algorithm eliminates 1 triangular product, 1 triangular solve, and 1 Cholesky factorization compared to the current algorithm, while adding no additional operations. ### Describe the solution you'd like. I propose adopting the new algorithm. From a cursory glance, it seems `invwishart_gen` might subclass `wishart_gen` primarily so they can share the same `_standard_rvs` method. The new algorithm would have a different `_standard_rvs` method, so I wonder if it would make sense for `invwishart_gen` to subtype `wishart_gen` anymore. ### Describe alternatives you've considered. _No response_ ### Additional context (e.g. screenshots, GIFs) Here are the relevant sections of the paper: And here is a reference implementation: https://github.com/sethaxen/rand_invwishart/tree/main/RandomInverseWishart.jl

comment.body: I noticed `invwishart_gen._logpdf` also Cholesky factorizes `scale`,  Cholesky factorizes `x` to invert it to `xinv`, then Cholesky factorizes `xinv` again to compute the logpdf. We can at least eliminate one factorization using the transform in the paper (without the change of variables), so I'll add that to the PR as well with a benchmark.

issue.title: Verify MKL works with Meson build, and document BLAS/LAPACK selection better

labels.name: task
labels.description: A straightforward change, verification or fix.

labels.name: Meson
labels.description: Items related to the introduction of Meson as the new build system for SciPy

issue.body:
After gh-16187 is complete, I think solid MKL support is a last blocker for shipping 1.9.0 with Meson. Building against MKL should work with `pkg-config`, however conda-forge `.pc` files are missing. And we'd like more robust support beyond `pkg-config`, in particular for MKL but also for other libraries. Relevant issues:
- https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/2835
- https://github.com/conda-forge/intel_repack-feedstock/issues/34

comment.body:
MKL versions shipped on conda-forge, PyPI and Spack are full of bugs, so it's hard to write a robust guide. I'd suggest to:
1. Install the very latest MKL, currently 2023.2.0; the one from Intel's standalone installed that goes into `/opt/intel/` is currently most reliable.
2. Run `source /opt/intel/oneapi/setvars.sh`
3. Ensure your `pip` is up-to-date, at least 23.1
4. Run `pip install . -Csetup-args=-Dblas=mkl-sdl -Csetup-args=-Dlapack=mkl-sdl`

That's about as easy as it gets right now. More robust support will come soon; it's rolled out in NumPy 1.26.1 already.

pages.title: *Release Note Entries for SciPy 1.12.0 (asterisk makes this appear at the top)

issue.title: ENH: Implemented Rotation.from_davenport and Rotation.as_davenport

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A new feature or improvement

issue.body:
#### Reference issue
This is a follow-up to #17392.

#### What does this implement/fix?
Davenport angles are a generalization of Euler angles.
Implemented the function `Rotation.as_davenport`, and for convenience, an inverse function called `Rotation.from_davenport` that makes internal calls to `Rotation.from_rotvec` but using the same type of parameters as `Rotation.as_davenport`. 

#### Additional information

Not any generalization is possible, basically we must have `dot(n1, n2) = dot(n2, n3) = 0`, like in Euler angles.
Moreover, for Euler angles: `dot(n1, n3) = 0, 1` or `-1`. For Davenport angles, this last can be any value between `-1` and `1` instead ([Source](https://doi.org/10.1007/BF03546304)).

This is a follow-up to my implementation of a new algorithm for `Rotation.as_euler()` based on [this paper (open access)](https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0276302). I now implemented a slightly modified version of the same algorithm to compute the Davenport angles for a set of input axes in the function.

In this implementation, there may be some set differences between the angles computed for the same axes by `Rotation.as_davenport` and `Rotation.as_euler` for some asymmetrical cases, but these different angles represent the same final rotation.

comment.body: @evbernardes Great working with you. Come back with new ideas!

commits.message:
ENH: Implemented Rotation.from_davenport and Rotation.as_davenport (#17728)

Co-authored-by: evbernardes <evbernardes@gmail.com>

pull_request.title: ENH: Implemented Rotation.from_davenport and Rotation.as_davenport
pull_request.body:
#### Reference issue
This is a follow-up to #17392.

#### What does this implement/fix?
Davenport angles are a generalization of Euler angles.
Implemented the function `Rotation.as_davenport`, and for convenience, an inverse function called `Rotation.from_davenport` that makes internal calls to `Rotation.from_rotvec` but using the same type of parameters as `Rotation.as_davenport`. 

#### Additional information

Not any generalization is possible, basically we must have `dot(n1, n2) = dot(n2, n3) = 0`, like in Euler angles.
Moreover, for Euler angles: `dot(n1, n3) = 0, 1` or `-1`. For Davenport angles, this last can be any value between `-1` and `1` instead ([Source](https://doi.org/10.1007/BF03546304)).

This is a follow-up to my implementation of a new algorithm for `Rotation.as_euler()` based on [this paper (open access)](https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0276302). I now implemented a slightly modified version of the same algorithm to compute the Davenport angles for a set of input axes in the function.

In this implementation, there may be some set differences between the angles computed for the same axes by `Rotation.as_davenport` and `Rotation.as_euler` for some asymmetrical cases, but these different angles represent the same final rotation.

labels.name: defect
labels.description: A clear bug or issue that prevents SciPy from being installed or used as expected

labels.name: C/C++
labels.description: Items related to the internal C/C++ code base

issue.body:
* Fixes #19436

* this applies a bug fix + regression test for the above issue, on the assumption that we should treat subnormals fairly similar to zero itself, and applies a similar patch to the `cdist`/`pdist` code paths as well

* note, however, that I'm not operating from a place of deep expertise here and I can think of a number of things we might want to check/fix up (note below), though I'd probably argue this makes more sense than returning infinity for these cases

* some additional things it might make sense to do: check another reference/implementation, write a test with subnormals at the end of the vectors instead of just at the start, write a test with more than 1 subnormal per vector (and do we actually know exactly what we want in all these cases...)

[skip cirrus] [skip circle]

comment.body: 32-bit CI failure is real, I'll mark as WIP for now since that surprised me.

issue.title: ENH: beta negative binomial distribution

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A new feature or improvement

issue.body:
#### Reference issue
Closes https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/17330

#### What does this implement/fix?
Adds the beta negative binomial distribution as `stats.betanbinom`.

#### Additional information
Pinging @jachymb who issued #17330: any help with the review is much appreciated.

The formulas for the moments were taken from [Wolfram Alpha](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=BetaNegativeBinomialDistribution%5B%5C%5BAlpha%5D%2C+%5C%5BBeta%5D%2C+n%5D).

Wolfram Alpha also contains a function for the CDF:
![image](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/assets/40656107/b003be6a-858f-4990-9628-1531f33a4852)

I decided not to implement that here as I am not sure if a naive implementation using the `special` functions (especially [`special.hyperu`](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.special.hyperu.html#scipy.special.hyperu), if that is the same generalized hypergeometric function from the Formula) will push this PR in a potentially very deep rabbit hole.

Somehow the `expect` method does not work with this distribution. I did not dig deeper in the discrete distribution infrastructure there though as that will be overhauled in future from what I understood.

Example:

```python

n, a, b = 5, 4.3, 1
from scipy.stats import betanbinom

dist = betanbinom(n, a, b)
dist.stats(moment="mvsk")

#  (1.5151515151515151, 7.1246057412065324, 477.61561430806694, 502.0609267840596)

dist.expect(lambda x: x), dist.expect(lambda x: x**2)
# RuntimeWarning: expect(): sum did not converge
#  warnings.warn('expect(): sum did not converge', RuntimeWarning)
# (1.5151510425851544, 9.419593400972543)
```

The results are similarly off with different parameter combinations for `n, a, b`.

comment.body:
> Have you checked a few more cases if the issue was indeed fisher vs pearson kurtosis? I tried a few parameters and the differences between k and ke were often very large. As Matt said, it could be an issue that the empirical estimates are not accurate, so I am not saying that the formula is wrong. I just think we should look at a few more examples and add a test case.

In the beginning, there was a typo in the formula which I corrected in bd52dc201bea821d3b7fee01295d43524428903c
. The correct formula and accounting for the different definitions results yields marching results now. I will post some more thorough checks in the next days.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,41 @@
+/* Evaluate polynomials.
+ *
+ * All of the coefficients are stored in reverse order, i.e. if the
+ * polynomial is
+ *
+ *     u_n x^n + u_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + ... + u_0,
+ *
+ * then coeffs[0] = u_n, coeffs[1] = u_{n - 1}, ..., coeffs[n] = u_0.
+ *
+ * References
+ * ----------
+ * [1] Knuth, "The Art of Computer Programming, Volume II"
+ */
+
+#pragma once
+
+#include <complex>
+
+
+inline std::complex<double> cevalpoly(const double *coeffs, int degree,
+				      std::complex<double> z) {
+    /* Evaluate a polynomial with real coefficients at a complex point.
+     *
+     * Uses equation (3) in section 4.6.4 of [1]. Note that it is more
+     * efficient than Horner's method.
+     */
+    int j;
+    double a = coeffs[0];
+    double b = coeffs[1];
+    double r = 2 * z.real();
+    double s = std::norm(z);
+    double tmp;
+
+    for (j = 2; j < degree + 1; j++) {
comment.body:
Well we are 1 function in and we already think the standard is rubbish so I guess nothing has changes since I stopped using C/C++ 😄 

Joking aside, I don't think this can actually matter since these are just a few bytes and not like large shaders or whatever. I'm pretty confident the standard is not talking to us with that paragraph.

pull_request.title: MAINT: Translate lambertw_scalar into C++
pull_request.body:
<!-- 
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure that
your PR satisfies the checklist before submitting:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#checklist-before-submitting-a-pr

Also, please name and describe your PR as you would write a
commit message:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message

Depending on your changes, you can skip CI operations and save time and energy: 
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/continuous_integration.html#skipping

Note that we are a team of volunteers; we appreciate your
patience during the review process.

Again, thanks for contributing!
-->

#### Reference issue
<!--Example: Closes gh-WXYZ.-->
This PR closes no issues, but this was discussed in the RFC issue gh-19404.

#### What does this implement/fix?
<!--Please explain your changes.-->
This PR rewrites the scalar kernel of the lambertw function in C++. The translation is as literal as possible, the only C++ism involved is the use of `std::complex`. Since the ufunc machinery in the numpy C API works with C doubles, I had to write a wrapper for C++ implementation which takes the complex argument as an `npy_cdouble`, converts to `std::complex<double>`, and then converts the output back into an `npy_cdouble`. This introduces some overhead, but the impact appears negligible.

`_lambertw.pxd` depended on `_evalpoly.pxd` which contains a polynomial evaluation implementation for polynomials with real coefficients and a complex argument. I've created a C++ implementation in `_evalpoly.h` which is again a direct translation of the corresponding Cython code. `_evalpoly.pxd` remains in place because it is a dependency of `_loggamma.pxd`. I could have made an `extern "C"` wrapper for the C++ code to be used in Cython, but we would lose the ability to inline this call. I think we can just have `_evalpoly.pxd` remain in place until `_loggamma.pxd` is translated.

 All functions are contained entirely in headers in order to facilitate the possible inclusion in other projects, as suggested by @izaid. I've verified that results are identical within machine precision on all test cases in `test_lambertw.py` (they could be completely identical, but I didn't check that).

#### Additional information
<!--Any additional information you think is important.-->
@izaid, please take a look and try the implementation out with CUDA. I'm curious how that works. I plan to work through the CUDA C++ programming guide and hope to be able to do stuff like that myself soon too. There's an open issue on CuPy for lambertw https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/4450. It would be nice if we could make a PR there as well in the near future.

#### Reference issue
<!--Example: Closes gh-WXYZ.-->

#### What does this implement/fix?
<!--Please explain your changes.-->
This PR rewrites the scalar kernel of the lambertw function in C++. The translation is as literal as possible, the only C++ism involved is the use of `std::complex`. Since the ufunc machinery in the numpy C API works with C doubles, I had to write a wrapper for C++ implementation which takes the complex argument as an `npy_cdouble`, converts to `std::complex<double>`, and then converts the output back into an `npy_cdouble`. This introduces some overhead, but the impact appears negligible.

`_lambertw.pxd` depended on `_evalpoly.pxd` which contains a polynomial evaluation implementation for polynomials with real coefficients and a complex argument. I've created a C++ implementation in `_evalpoly.h` which is again a direct translation of the corresponding Cython code. `_evalpoly.pxd` remains in place because it is a dependency of `_loggamma.pxd`. I could have made an `extern "C"` wrapper for the C++ code to be used in Cython, but we would lose the ability to inline this call. I think we can just have `_evalpoly.pxd` remain in place until `_loggamma.pxd` is translated.

 All functions are contained entirely in headers in order to facilitate the possible inclusion in other projects, as suggested by @izaid. I've verified that results are identical within machine precision on all test cases in `test_lambertw.py` (they could be completely identical, but I didn't check that).

#### Additional information
<!--Any additional information you think is important.-->
@izaid, please take a look and try the implementation out with CUDA. I'm curious how that works. I plan to work through the CUDA C++ programming guide and hope to be able to do stuff like that myself soon too. There's an open issue on CuPy for lambertw https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/4450. issue.title: ENH: beta negative binomial distribution

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A new feature or improvement

issue.body:
#### Reference issue
Closes https://github.com/scipy/scipy/issues/17330

#### What does this implement/fix?
Adds the beta negative binomial distribution as `stats.betanbinom`.

#### Additional information
Pinging @jachymb who issued #17330: any help with the review is much appreciated.

The formulas for the moments were taken from [Wolfram Alpha](https://www.wolframalpha.com/input?i=BetaNegativeBinomialDistribution%5B%5C%5BAlpha%5D%2C+%5C%5BBeta%5D%2C+n%5D).

Wolfram Alpha also contains a function for the CDF:
![image](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/assets/40656107/b003be6a-858f-4990-9628-1531f33a4852)

I decided not to implement that here as I am not sure if a naive implementation using the `special` functions (especially [`special.hyperu`](https://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/generated/scipy.special.hyperu.html#scipy.special.hyperu), if that is the same generalized hypergeometric function from the Formula) will push this PR in a potentially very deep rabbit hole.

Somehow the `expect` method does not work with this distribution. I did not dig deeper in the discrete distribution infrastructure there though as that will be overhauled in future from what I understood.

Example:

```python

n, a, b = 5, 4.3, 1
from scipy.stats import betanbinom

dist = betanbinom(n, a, b)
dist.stats(moment="mvsk")

#  (1.5151515151515151, 7.1246057412065324, 477.61561430806694, 502.0609267840596)

dist.expect(lambda x: x), dist.expect(lambda x: x**2)
# RuntimeWarning: expect(): sum did not converge
#  warnings.warn('expect(): sum did not converge', RuntimeWarning)
# (1.5151510425851544, 9.419593400972543)
```

The results are similarly off with different parameter combinations for `n, a, b`.

comment.body: Have you checked a few more cases if the issue was indeed fisher vs pearson kurtosis? I tried a few parameters and the differences between k and ke were often very large. As Matt said, it could be an issue that the empirical estimates are not accurate, so I am not saying that the formula is wrong. I just think we should look at a few more examples and add a test case.

Note that we are a team of volunteers; we appreciate your
patience during the review process.

Again, thanks for contributing!
-->

#### Reference issue
<!--Example: Closes gh-WXYZ.-->
This PR closes no issues, but this was discussed in the RFC issue gh-19404.

#### What does this implement/fix?
<!--Please explain your changes.-->
This PR rewrites the scalar kernel of the lambertw function in C++. The translation is as literal as possible, the only C++ism involved is the use of `std::complex`. Since the ufunc machinery in the numpy C API works with C doubles, I had to write a wrapper for C++ implementation which takes the complex argument as an `npy_cdouble`, converts to `std::complex<double>`, and then converts the output back into an `npy_cdouble`. This introduces some overhead, but the impact appears negligible.

`_lambertw.pxd` depended on `_evalpoly.pxd` which contains a polynomial evaluation implementation for polynomials with real coefficients and a complex argument. I've created a C++ implementation in `_evalpoly.h` which is again a direct translation of the corresponding Cython code. `_evalpoly.pxd` remains in place because it is a dependency of `_loggamma.pxd`. I could have made an `extern "C"` wrapper for the C++ code to be used in Cython, but we would lose the ability to inline this call. I think we can just have `_evalpoly.pxd` remain in place until `_loggamma.pxd` is translated.

 All functions are contained entirely in headers in order to facilitate the possible inclusion in other projects, as suggested by @izaid. I've verified that results are identical within machine precision on all test cases in `test_lambertw.py` (they could be completely identical, but I didn't check that).

#### Additional information

I plan to work through the CUDA C++ programming guide and hope to be able to do stuff like that myself soon too. There's an open issue on CuPy for lambertw https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/4450. It would be nice if we could make a PR there as well in the near future.

comment.body:
> > > > I do think that the special function code should all be in a namespace to prevent name clashing. Just `namespace scipy { namespace special { ... } }` would be enough. I don't think the functions in `extra_special.h` need to be in a namespace.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Good idea. Done. Should I put the helper functions in an anonymous namespace to make them private, or is that unnecessary?
> > 
> > 
> > Do you mean the ones in `extra_special.h`? If yes, I wouldn't worry about them, as I think they'll only be used by SciPy.
> 
> Sorry, I meant stuff like `lambertw_branchpt` and `lambertw_pade0`. The things used internally by the main `lambertw` implementatoin.

I don't think this matters so much right now, but it might be something we have to do at some point. Another common option is a `detail` namespace, i.e. `namespace scipy { namespace special { namespace detail { ... } } }`. But I'd probably just leave it alone for now.

This effectively amounts to "do nothing for subnormals" in this control flow I think (add in something that is basically zero). Per my original comment, should probably try moving the subnormal to the last element in the array as well, to see if i.e., `q_i` would also benefit from a similar shim (assuming this is what we actually want to do).

* note, however, that I'm not operating from a place of deep expertise here and I can think of a number of things we might want to check/fix up (note below), though I'd probably argue this makes more sense than returning infinity for these cases

* some additional things it might make sense to do: check another reference/implementation, write a test with subnormals at the end of the vectors instead of just at the start, write a test with more than 1 subnormal per vector (and do we actually know exactly what we want in all these cases...)

pull_request.title: BUG: handle subnormals jensenshannon
pull_request.body:
* Fixes #19436

* this applies a bug fix + regression test for the above issue, on the assumption that we should treat subnormals fairly similar to zero itself, and applies a similar patch to the `cdist`/`pdist` code paths as well

* note, however, that I'm not operating from a place of deep expertise here and I can think of a number of things we might want to check/fix up (note below), though I'd probably argue this makes more sense than returning infinity for these cases

* some additional things it might make sense to do: check another reference/implementation, write a test with subnormals at the end of the vectors instead of just at the start, write a test with more than 1 subnormal per vector (and do we actually know exactly what we want in all these cases...)

[skip cirrus] [skip circle]

pull_request.title: MAINT: Translate lambertw_scalar into C++
pull_request.body:
<!-- 
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure that
your PR satisfies the checklist before submitting:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#checklist-before-submitting-a-pr

Also, please name and describe your PR as you would write a
commit message:
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/development_workflow.html#writing-the-commit-message

Depending on your changes, you can skip CI operations and save time and energy: 
http://scipy.github.io/devdocs/dev/contributor/continuous_integration.html#skipping

Note that we are a team of volunteers; we appreciate your
patience during the review process.

Again, thanks for contributing!
-->

#### Reference issue
<!--Example: Closes gh-WXYZ.-->
This PR closes no issues, but this was discussed in the RFC issue gh-19404.

#### What does this implement/fix?
<!--Please explain your changes.-->
This PR rewrites the scalar kernel of the lambertw function in C++. The translation is as literal as possible, the only C++ism involved is the use of `std::complex`. Since the ufunc machinery in the numpy C API works with C doubles, I had to write a wrapper for C++ implementation which takes the complex argument as an `npy_cdouble`, converts to `std::complex<double>`, and then converts the output back into an `npy_cdouble`. This introduces some overhead, but the impact appears negligible.

`_lambertw.pxd` depended on `_evalpoly.pxd` which contains a polynomial evaluation implementation for polynomials with real coefficients and a complex argument. I've created a C++ implementation in `_evalpoly.h` which is again a direct translation of the corresponding Cython code. `_evalpoly.pxd` remains in place because it is a dependency of `_loggamma.pxd`. I could have made an `extern "C"` wrapper for the C++ code to be used in Cython, but we would lose the ability to inline this call. I think we can just have `_evalpoly.pxd` remain in place until `_loggamma.pxd` is translated.

 All functions are contained entirely in headers in order to facilitate the possible inclusion in other projects, as suggested by @izaid. I've verified that results are identical within machine precision on all test cases in `test_lambertw.py` (they could be completely identical, but I didn't check that).

#### Additional information
<!--Any additional information you think is important.-->
@izaid, please take a look and try the implementation out with CUDA. I'm curious how that works. I plan to work through the CUDA C++ programming guide and hope to be able to do stuff like that myself soon too. There's an open issue on CuPy for lambertw https://github.com/cupy/cupy/issues/4450. It would be nice if we could make a PR there as well in the near future.

comment.body: I changed it to declare the loop indices at first use, and fixed a place where I had an empty declaration and then put the definition on the next line. The variable `absz` could  be changed to be declared at first use in `lambertw` in `_lambertw.h`, but I don't think any of the others could be changed without torturing the code in some way, since each of `w`, `wz`, `wew` and `wewz` and `wn` are defined deep in nested logic, and in different ways in different branches.

issue.title: ENH: Faster inverse-Wishart sampling

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: A new feature or improvement

issue.body: ### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. Currently inverse-Wishart sampling ([here](https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/d7f12d38b171f3a6ae841937bb6c2444a1e04b8d/scipy/stats/_multivariate.py#L2957-L3004)) Cholesky decomposes the scale matrix to invert it, then Cholesky decomposes its inverse, samples a Cholesky factor from the Wishart distribution, then inverts it to form an inverse-Wishart matrix. Algorithm 5 in https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.15884v1 generates a Cholesky factor of an inverse-Wishart matrix directly. Table 1 shows that for the $\Psi$ parameterization used in `invwishart`, this algorithm eliminates 1 triangular product, 1 triangular solve, and 1 Cholesky factorization compared to the current algorithm, while adding no additional operations. ### Describe the solution you'd like. I propose adopting the new algorithm. From a cursory glance, it seems `invwishart_gen` might subclass `wishart_gen` primarily so they can share the same `_standard_rvs` method. The new algorithm would have a different `_standard_rvs` method, so I wonder if it would make sense for `invwishart_gen` to subtype `wishart_gen` anymore. ### Describe alternatives you've considered. _No response_ ### Additional context (e.g. screenshots, GIFs) Here are the relevant sections of the paper: And here is a reference implementation: https://github.com/sethaxen/rand_invwishart/tree/main/RandomInverseWishart.jl

comment.body:
Here's a numerical check that the log-density of $Z$ implied by Theorem 3.2 agrees with the change of variables we get by explicitly transforming the inverse-Wishart to $Z$ and computing the log-det-Jacobian using autodiff:

```python
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import chi, norm, invwishart
import jax

def triu_to_vec(x):
    y = x[np.triu_indices_from(x)]
    return y

def vec_to_triu_jax(y):
    dim = (int((8 * len(y) + 1)**0.5) - 1) // 2
    x = jax.numpy.zeros((dim, dim), dtype=jax.numpy.float64)
    x = x.at[np.triu_indices(dim)].set(y)
    return x

def transform(Z, UOmega):
    UB = jax.scipy.linalg.solve_triangular(Z, UOmega)
    B = UB.T @ UB
    return B

def rand_chol_upper(dim):
    Z = np.linalg.qr(np.random.randn(dim, dim))[1]
    Z[np.diag_indices(dim)] = np.fabs(Z[np.diag_indices(dim)])
    return Z

def logpdf_direct(Z, df):
    dim = Z.shape[0]
    lp = norm.logpdf(Z[np.triu_indices(dim, 1)]).sum()
    lp += chi.logpdf(np.diag(Z), df=df - dim + np.arange(dim) + 1).sum()
    return lp

def logpdf_change_of_variables(Z, df, UOmega):
    B = transform(Z, UOmega)
    f = lambda z: triu_to_vec(transform(vec_to_triu_jax(z), Uscale))
    J = jax.jacfwd(f)(triu_to_vec(Z))
    logdetJ = np.linalg.slogdet(J)[1]
    Omega = UOmega.T @ UOmega
    lp = invwishart.logpdf(B, df=df, scale=Omega) + logdetJ
    return lp

for dim in range(1, 11):
    for df in (dim, dim + 3):
        Z = rand_chol_upper(dim)
        Uscale = rand_chol_upper(dim)
        lp1 = logpdf_direct(Z, df)
        lp2 = logpdf_change_of_variables(Z, df, Uscale)
        assert np.isclose(lp1, lp2)
```

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,41 @@
+/* Evaluate polynomials.
+ *
+ * All of the coefficients are stored in reverse order, i.e. if the
+ * polynomial is
+ *
+ *     u_n x^n + u_{n - 1} x^{n - 1} + ... + u_0,
+ *
+ * then coeffs[0] = u_n, coeffs[1] = u_{n - 1}, ..., coeffs[n] = u_0.
+ *
+ * References
+ * ----------
+ * [1] Knuth, "The Art of Computer Programming, Volume II"
+ */
+
+#pragma once
+
+#include <complex>
+
+
+inline std::complex<double> cevalpoly(const double *coeffs, int degree,
+				      std::complex<double> z) {
+    /* Evaluate a polynomial with real coefficients at a complex point.
+     *
+     * Uses equation (3) in section 4.6.4 of [1]. Note that it is more
+     * efficient than Horner's method.
+     */
+    int j;
+    double a = coeffs[0];
+    double b = coeffs[1];
+    double r = 2 * z.real();
+    double s = std::norm(z);
+    double tmp;
+
+    for (j = 2; j < degree + 1; j++) {
comment.body:
I see, from the ISOCpp link

*Declare near first use.*

*An object is initialized (constructed) the moment it is declared. If you don’t have enough information to initialize an object until half way down the function, you should create it half way down the function when it can be initialized correctly. Don’t initialize it to an “empty” value at the top then “assign” it later. The reason for this is runtime performance. Building an object correctly is faster than building it incorrectly and remodeling it later. Simple examples show a factor of 350% speed hit for simple classes like String. Your mileage may vary; surely the overall system degradation will be less that 350%, but there will be degradation. Unnecessary degradation.*

I'll check if there's actually a noticeable performance hit and will defer to @ilayn if not.
